priorVersion.title: CDISC SDTM Respiratory Test Code Terminology

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor resource for codelist C111106

self.title: CDISC SDTM Respiratory Test Code Terminology

definition: A terminology codelist based on the test codes for physiological findings related to the respiratory system, including the organs that are involved in breathing such as the nose, throat, larynx, trachea, bronchi and lungs.
name: Respiratory Test Code
preferredTerm: CDISC SDTM Respiratory Test Code Terminology

terms.definition: A determination of additional abnormalities and/or other observations that may be associated with the disease of interest, for which a targeted test has not been identified in the data.
A measurement of the gas retention in a specified intrapulmonary space at the end of exhalation.
The quantity of gas that enters the alveoli during inspiration.
The total volume of gas in a specified airway or set of airways at a specified point in time in the respiratory cycle.
The total volume of gas in a specified airway or set of airways at a specified point in time in the respiratory cycle, expressed as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
The volume of the entirety of the airway tissue in a specified intrapulmonary region.
The volume of blood per unit time passing through a specified location, such as a point in a blood vessel or an entire organ.
The volume of the carbon monoxide that is transferred from inspired air into the pulmonary capillary blood.
synonyms: Diffusion Capacity of Lung for CO
Transfer Factor of Lung for CO

terms.definition: The diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide adjusted for hemoglobin concentration.
terms.preferredTerm: Hemoglobin Corrected Diffusion Capacity of the Lung for Carbon Monoxide

terms.definition: The diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide expressed as a proportion of the predicted normal value, adjusted for hemoglobin concentration.
terms.preferredTerm: Percent Predicted Hemoglobin Corrected Diffusion Capacity of the Lung for Carbon Monoxide

terms.definition: The diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide expressed as a proportion of the alveolar volume, adjusted for hemoglobin concentration.
terms.preferredTerm: Hemoglobin Corrected Diffusion Capacity of the Lung for Carbon Monoxide/Alveolar Volume Ratio

terms.definition: The proportion of diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide to the alveolar volume expressed as a proportion of the predicted normal value, adjusted for hemoglobin concentration.
terms.preferredTerm: Percent Predicted Hemoglobin Corrected Diffusion Capacity of the Lung for Carbon Monoxide/Alveolar Volume Ratio

terms.definition: The mean volume of the carbon monoxide that is transferred from inspired air into the pulmonary capillary blood.
terms.preferredTerm: Mean Carbon Monoxide Diffusing Capability Test
synonyms: Mean Diffusion Capacity of Lung for CO

terms.definition: The diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide expressed as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
terms.preferredTerm: Percent Predicted Diffusion Capacity of the Lung for Carbon Monoxide

terms.definition: The diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide expressed as a proportion of the alveolar volume.
terms.preferredTerm: Diffusion Capacity of the Lung for Carbon Monoxide/Alveolar Volume Ratio

terms.definition: The proportion of the diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide to alveolar volume, expressed as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
terms.preferredTerm: Percent Predicted Diffusion Capacity of the Lung for Carbon Monoxide/Alveolar Volume Ratio

terms.definition: A subjective assessment of the primary lung abnormality pattern, generally based on size, distribution, and/or amount.
A subjective assessment of the distribution of the primary lung abnormality pattern.
An indication as to whether effusion is present.
The amount of three dimensional space occupied by the effusion fluid.
A measure of the resistance of a system to expand, i.e. the pressure change that is required to elicit a unit volume change in the lungs. Elastance is the reciprocal of compliance.
The maximum volume of air a subject can exhale from the lungs after a tidal exhalation.
The maximum volume of air a subject can exhale from the lungs after a tidal exhalation as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
The ratio of the volume of gas that is forcibly exhaled during the first 0.05 seconds following maximal inhalation to that of the forced vital capacity.
terms.preferredTerm: Forced Expiratory Volume in 0.05 Second to FVC Ratio Measurement
synonyms: Forced Expiratory Volume in 0.05 Seconds over FVC

terms.definition: The ratio of the volume of gas that is forcibly exhaled during the first 0.1 seconds following maximal inhalation to that of the forced vital capacity.
terms.preferredTerm: Forced Expiratory Volume in 0.1 Second to FVC Ratio Measurement
synonyms: Forced Expiratory Volume in 0.1 Seconds over FVC

terms.definition: The ratio of the volume of gas that is forcibly exhaled during the first 0.2 seconds following maximal inhalation to that of the forced vital capacity.
terms.preferredTerm: Forced Expiratory Volume in 0.2 Second to FVC Ratio Measurement
synonyms: Forced Expiratory Volume in 0.2 Seconds over FVC

terms.definition: The maximum volume of air an individual can exhale from the point of maximal inhalation.
The maximum volume of air an individual can exhale from the point of maximal inhalation as a percentage of the predicted normal value.
The time required to exhale 63.2% of the total expiratory volume, as measured from the start of exhalation.
The mean forced expiratory flow rate at 25-75% of the forced vital capacity. (NCI)
The mean forced expiratory flow rate at 25-75% of the forced vital capacity as a proportion of the predicted normal value. (NCI)
terms.preferredTerm: Percent Predicted Forced Expiratory Flow at 25-75 Percent

terms.definition: The mean forced expiratory flow rate at 50% of the forced vital capacity. (NCI)
terms.preferredTerm: Forced Expiratory Flow at 50 Percent Forced Vital Capacity

terms.definition: The forced expiratory flow rate during the first 0.05 second of a forced exhalation.
The forced expiratory flow rate during the first 0.1 second of a forced exhalation.
The forced expiratory flow rate during the first 0.2 second of a forced exhalation.
The volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled during the first second following maximal inhalation.
A relative measurement (ratio or percentage) of the forced expiratory volume during the first second of exhalation to the largest observed expired volume during a forced vital capacity maneuver.
terms.preferredTerm: Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 Second to Forced Vital Capacity Ratio Measurement

terms.definition: A relative measurement (ratio or percentage) of the forced expiratory volume during the first second of exhalation to the observed expired volume during the first six seconds of a forced vital capacity maneuver.
terms.preferredTerm: Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 Second to Forced Vital Capacity in 6 Seconds

terms.definition: The proportion of total forced vital capacity that is expelled during the first second of a forced exhalation as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
terms.preferredTerm: Percent Predicted Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 Second Divided by Forced Vital Capacity

terms.definition: Forced expiratory volume in one second as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
terms.preferredTerm: Percent Predicted Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 Second

terms.definition: The change in FEV1 following administration of a bronchodilator relative to the pre-treatment FEV1 value.
terms.preferredTerm: Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 Second Reversibility

terms.definition: A relative measurement (ratio or percentage) of the forced expiratory volume during the first second of exhalation to the largest observed expired volume during a slow vital capacity maneuver.
terms.preferredTerm: Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 Second to Slow Vital Capacity Ratio Measurement

terms.definition: The volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled during the first three seconds following maximal inhalation.

A relative measurement (ratio or percentage) of the forced expiratory volume during the first three seconds of exhalation to the largest observed expired volume during a forced vital capacity maneuver.
terms.preferredTerm: Forced Expiratory Volume in 3 Seconds to Forced Vital Capacity Ratio Measurement

terms.definition: Forced expiratory volume in three seconds as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
terms.preferredTerm: Percent Predicted Forced Expiratory Volume in 3 Seconds

terms.definition: The volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled during the first six seconds following maximal inhalation.
Forced expiratory volume in six seconds as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
terms.preferredTerm: Percent Predicted Forced Expiratory Volume in 6 Seconds

terms.definition: The volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled during the first 0.05 second following maximal inhalation.
The volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled during the first 0.1 second following maximal inhalation.
The volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled during the first 0.2 second following maximal inhalation.
The volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled during the first half second following maximal inhalation.
The volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled during the first 0.75 second following maximal inhalation.
The volume of gas that is forcibly exhaled at the peak of expiratory flow.
terms.preferredTerm: Forced Expiratory Volume at Peak Expiratory Flow
synonyms: Forced Expiratory Volume at Peak Expiratory Flow

terms.definition: The forced inspiratory flow rate at the point on the inspiratory flow-volume curve where 25 percent of the total volume of air has been inhaled.
The forced inspiratory flow rate at the point on the inspiratory flow-volume curve where 50 percent of the total volume of air has been inhaled.
The forced inspiratory flow rate at the point on the inspiratory flow-volume curve where 75 percent of the total volume of air has been inhaled.
The fastest rate of inspired air achieved during a forced inspiration maneuver.
The fastest rate of inspired air achieved during a forced inspiration maneuver expressed as a percentage of the expected result value for healthy individuals with similar characteristics.
terms.preferredTerm: Percent Predicted Forced Inspiratory Flow Maximum

terms.definition: A measurement of the volumetric fraction of oxygen in the inhaled gas.
The volume of air that a subject can breathe in during the first second of inhalation after maximum exhalation.
The volume of air that a subject can breathe in during the first second of inhalation after maximum exhalation as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
terms.preferredTerm: Percent Predicted Forced Inspiratory Volume in 1 Second

terms.definition: The difference in lung volume between maximal expiration to residual volume followed immediately by full inspiration to total lung capacity during forceful inhalation.
The volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal exhalation. (NCI)
The functional residual capacity as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
The volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled following maximal inhalation.
The volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled during the first six seconds following maximal inhalation.
Forced vital capacity as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
The instantaneous rate of air flow in the airway, expressed as the pressure difference between any given part of the airway and the alveoli; it is the reciprocal of airway resistance (Raw).
The maximum volume of air a subject can inhale into the lungs after a tidal exhalation (IRV plus TV).
The maximum volume of air a subject can inhale into the lungs after a tidal exhalation (IRV plus TV) as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
The change in IC following administration of a bronchodilator relative to the pre-treatment IC value.
The measure of the force of the column of air in the conducting airways.
An indication as to whether infiltrates have occurred.

An act or process of elucidation; explication, or explanation of the meaning of the event or thing via the assignment of objects from the domain to the constants of a formal language, truth-values to the proposition symbols, truth-functions to the connectives, other functions to the function symbols, and extensions to the predicates, if any. The assignments are result of human logic application and are not native to the symbols of the formal language.
The maximum volume of air a subject can inhale into the lungs after a tidal inhalation.
The maximum volume of air a subject can inhale into the lungs after a tidal inhalation as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
The maximum volume of air an individual can inhale from the point of maximal exhalation.
The maximum volume of air an individual can inhale from the point of maximal exhalation as a percentage of the predicted normal value.

A representative measurement of the number of times the volume of air in the lung at the start of the washout (the Functional Residual Capacity) must be recycled to eliminate the tracer to the pre-defined endpoint.
The total volume of gas in a lobe of the lung at a specified point in time during the respiratory cycle.
The total volume of gas in a lobe of the lung at a specified point in time during the respiratory cycle, as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
The basis for the determination that a malignancy is present.
An indication as to whether a malignancy is present.
The greatest amount of pressure that can be generated by exhaling against a mouthpiece, which is a measure of the strength of respiratory muscles. (NCI)

The greatest amount of pressure that can be generated by exhaling against a mouthpiece, which is a measure of the strength of respiratory muscles expressed as a proportion of the predicted normal value. (NCI)
The greatest amount of pressure that can be generated during inhalation against a fully occluded airway, which is used to measure the strength of respiratory muscles. (NCI)

The greatest amount of pressure that can be generated during inhalation against a fully occluded airway, which is used to measure the strength of respiratory muscles expressed as a proportion of the predicted normal value. (NCI)

A measurement of the efficiency of oxygen exchange by the lungs, which is calculated by multiplying the fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) (in %) to mean airway pressure (Mpaw), and dividing by pressure of arterial oxygen (PaO2).
The volume of oxygen per heartbeat consumed by the body while at rest.
The maximum rate of air flow expelled through the mouth, endotracheal, or tracheostomy tube during a cough. (NCI)
The maximum rate of exhalation.
The maximal flow achieved during the maximally forced expiration initiated at maximum inhalation as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
The change in PEF following administration of a bronchodilator relative to the pre-treatment PEF value.
The time from the start of the test until the subject reaches his maximum expiratory gas flow rate.
The maximum rate of inhalation.
A measurement of the ability of the lung to store energy, which is required for passive expiration.
An indication as to whether pneumonia has occurred.
The maximal flow achieved during the maximally forced inspiration through the nose initiated at maximum exhalation. (NCI)
A relative measurement (ratio or percentage) of the force per unit area (pressure) of oxygen dissolved in arterial blood to the percentage oxygen of an inhaled mixture of gasses.
terms.preferredTerm: Partial Pressure Arterial Oxygen to Fraction Inspired Oxygen Ratio Measurement

terms.definition: The static elastic recoil pressure of the lungs at a given lung volume.
A measurement of respiratory tract resistance to airflow during inspiration and expiration.
A measurement of respiratory tract resistance to airflow during inspiration and expiration, as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
An observation, assessment or examination of the respiratory system.
An assessment of the size difference in comparison to a baseline or previous value.
The ratio between the amount of carbon dioxide produced and oxygen consumed in one breath.
A calculated value based on all factors that influence the flow of gas from the airway opening to the alveoli, including airway resistance, and tissue resistance of the lung and chest wall. (NCI)
The volume of air remaining in the lungs after maximum exhalation.
The volume of air remaining in the lungs after maximum exhalation as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
A representation of the exponential function described by the Salazar-Knowles equation, and an estimation of a subject's inspiratory capacity.
The difference between the volume at total lung capacity and the hypothesized volume at a transpulmonary pressure of zero.
The reflection of the curvature of the upper portion of the deflationary limb of the pressure-volume curve.
A relative measurement (ratio or percentage) of the oxygen-hemoglobin saturation of a volume of blood to the volumetric fraction of oxygen in the inhaled gas.
A parameter used in functional respiratory imaging, derived by dividing the airway volume of a specified intrapulmonary region by the total volume of the same specified intrapulmonary region.

A parameter used in functional respiratory imaging, derived by dividing the airway volume of a specified intrapulmonary region by the total volume of the same specified intrapulmonary region, expressed as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
A measurement of the airway conductance relative to lung volume. (NCI)
A measurement used to describe airway behavior irrespective of lung volume; it is calculated as airway resistance (Raw) multiplied by functional residual capacity (FRC).

A measurement used to describe airway behavior irrespective of lung volume; it is calculated as airway resistance (Raw) multiplied by functional residual capacity (FRC), as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
The maximum volume of air that can be exhaled after slow maximum inhalation.
The maximum volume of air that can be exhaled after slow maximum inhalation as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
The absolute volume of air contained in the thoracic cavity at any given point in time and at any level of alveolar pressure.
The total volume of air in the lungs after maximum inhalation.
The total volume of air in the lungs after maximum inhalation as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
A measurement of the reflection of energy conservation within a given tissue.

The energy dissipated relative to the elastic energy stored in the tissue in a P-V cycle. (Fredberg JJ, Stamenovic D. On the imperfect elasticity of lung tissue. J Appl Physiol (1985). 1989 Dec;67(6):2408-19).
The volume of air moved into and out of the lungs during breathing at rest.
The volume of air moved into and out of the lungs during breathing at rest as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
The rate at which oxygen is absorbed and utilized by any given tissue in the body.
The maximum rate of oxygen utilization at which oxygen uptake no longer increases and beyond which no level of effort can raise it.
The predicted maximum rate of oxygen uptake that is derived from physiological responses to submaximal exercise performance and is used as a measure of cardiorespiratory fitness.
